10.name: Whole-Body Breathing
10.subtitle: How to transform sensory stimulation into intimate body breathing.

quote.text: "They train themselves: 'I will breathe in sensitive to the entire body.' They train themselves: 'I will breathe out sensitive to the entire body'."

10.overview: As you become skilled in developing tranquillity, you no longer need to practice Skills 07-09. From Skill 06: Whole of Each Breath, you will now gradually become more aware of the pleasurable experience of your whole body as it breathes in Skill 10, to withdraw awareness from the six sense fields.
benefits: This Skill will teach you to develop calmness and non-reactivity to sensory experiences so that your mind is less disturbed by stimulation throughout the day.
10.purpose: Withdraw peripheral awareness from your six sense fields to increase mental seclusion in preparation for access concentration and jhana (wholesome absorption).
tips: Increased intimacy with the subtle pleasure of your whole-body breathing will withdraw your awareness from the stimulation of your six senses. As sensitivity to your senses fades, body-breathing will transition from a physical meditation object in Skill 10 to a mind-created one in Skill 11, taking the experience of piti-sukha as an object.

progression.criteria: You are ready to progress to Meditation Skill 11: Sustained Awareness when you become intimately aware of the experience of your whole-body breathing as a pleasurable breath experience, and your awareness of your five physical senses begins to fade (viraga).

11.name: Sustained Awareness
11.subtitle: How to transform anticipation of pleasure into sustained awareness.
11.duration: 60 minutes, twice per day, to give your mind time to develop sukha and absorb into the pleasurable piti feeling.

quote.text: "They train themself: 'I will breathe in experiencing to piti.' They train themself: 'I will breathe out experiencing to piti.' They train themself: 'I will breathe in experiencing sukha.' They train themself: 'I will breathe out experiencing sukha'."

11.overview: With ever increasing intimacy of your awareness with the pleasurable experience of your whole-body as it breathes, your sense doors, including your body sense will fade, replaced with an overall awareness of growing blissful pleasure born of letting go in the body and mind.
benefits: This Meditation Skill will teach your mind to let go of interest in sensory stimulation in daily life through increased intimacy with the pleasure of letting go within your body and breathing experience.
11.purpose: Increase your mind's intimacy with the enjoyment of your whole-body breathing so that body perception fades and the pleasure of piti and sukha remain as your meditation object for accessing the first pleasure jhana.
tips: As you become more aware of the experience of breathing throughout your whole body, you will find that your awareness begins to develop an intimacy with it. Intimacy of awareness refers to the exclusivity of attention you give to someone you care about, letting them know how much you care, free from any external distractions. As the intimacy of your awareness of whole-body breathing increases, the boundaries of your body and the sensations within it will fade. This is not a sign of dullness, as your mind at this stage is beyond it, but rather an observation of the gradual shutting down of the body's sensory doors because your mind no longer gives importance to them. This same process is happening to your other senses, but because of your exclusive awareness of your body, it will not be as obvious.

progression.criteria: When you become aware of an increased feeling of steadiness of awareness accompanied by fading of the sense fields and the sensations in your body fade, leaving an increasingly pleasurable, blissful feeling (piti) and joyful happiness (sukha) that fills the experience of your awareness.

12.name: Access Concentration
12.subtitle: How to transform fear of letting go into letting go in access concentration
12.duration: 60 minutes, twice per day, to give your mind time to absorb into piti. This stage requires a simplification of your life, adherence to sila (morality) and inclining your mind toward that which is kusala (wholesome/skilful). Organised Buddhist meditation retreats create the perfect conditions for accelerating your practice from this point.

quote.text: "Secluded from the desire for sensory experience, secluded from unwholesome qualities."

12.overview: As intimacy increases, awareness also becomes steady, firm, unmoving, effortless, and unified, free from all hindrances, with a growing presence of blissful pleasant feelings in the body (piti) and joyful happiness (sukha) within the heart/mind, allowing for access to concentration to establish.
benefits: This Meditation Skill will teach your mind to incline toward and absorb into wholesome (kusala) pleasure in daily life by releasing interest in habitual identification with hindrances and increased disenchantment with sensory stimulation.
12.purpose: To develop your skill in reaching and resting in access concentration in preparation for the first pleasure jhana.
tips: If tranquillity and letting go are mature at access concentration, piti will be calm and unexcited with sukha dominant. If tranquillity and letting go are immature, then piti may arise as quite strong waves of blissful, pleasant feelings that disturb the tranquillity and, at times, are unpleasant.

progression.criteria: You are ready to progress when you are comfortable developing access concentration and can remain in it for at least 15 minutes with the pleasant feeling of piti remaining stable within the awareness of your body without fading. Congratulations, you have finished Cultivation 04.

13.name: First Pleasure Jhana
13.subtitle: How to enter the first pleasure jhana through intimacy with piti (blissful pleasure)
13.duration: 60 minutes, 2-3 times daily, to give your mind time to absorb into piti and abide in the first pleasure jhana. This stage requires a simplification of your life, adherence to sila (morality) and inclining your mind toward that which is kusala (wholesome/skilful).

quote.text: "Secluded from the desire for sensory experience, secluded from unwholesome qualities, a meditator enters and dwells within the first jhana, with applied and sustained attention, blissful feelings in body & mind, and joyful happiness born of seclusion."

13.overview: As your samadhi reaches access concentration in Skill 12, you continue to develop intimacy with the pleasantness of the experience of piti within your body and mind, until your mind takes it as an object within your samadhi and flows with and absorbs into it to enter the first pleasure jhana.
benefits: Regularly entering and experiencing the first pleasure jhana will weaken your mind's attraction to extracting pleasure from worldly experiences (including thinking) and develop an inclination of your mind toward the spiritual pleasure that is only available through letting go of desire for worldly sensory pleasure.
13.purpose: Unify in access concentration on the blissful, pleasant feeling of piti of your whole-body breathing, and allow the feeling of joy and happiness of sukha to rest in peripheral awareness.
tips: Play around with where you experience the pleasant piti feeling most clearly. Using the MIDL technique, maintain a continuous, heartfelt smile through your eyes. This brings up a clear, pleasant sensation around your eyes and forehead. Some meditators experience clear pleasant feeling in their chest, heart centre, or in their hands. Some report experiencing it in their legs or spine as an upward-moving, pleasurable energy. Wherever you experience the pleasantness of piti is ok; the important part is to let it be and enjoy its presence.

progression.criteria: You are comfortable developing and abiding in the first pleasure jhana for longer periods, and your mind is inclining away from the stimulation of piti toward the subtler happiness of sukha.

14.name: Second Pleasure Jhana
14.subtitle: How to transform blissful pleasure into joyful happiness through refined sukha
14.duration: 60 minutes, 2-3 times daily, to give your mind time to absorb into sukha and abide in the second pleasure jhana. This stage requires a simplification of your life, adherence to sila (morality) and inclining your mind toward that which is kusala (wholesome/skilful). Organised Buddhist meditation retreats create the perfect conditions for accelerating your practice from this point.

quote.text: "With the calming of applied & sustained attention, the meditator enters & dwells within the second jhana, with inner calming & unification of mind, free from thinking & reflection, and filled with blissful feelings in body & mind and joyful happiness born of unification."

14.overview: As the experience of the blissful, pleasant feeling of piti calms, intimacy with the joyfulness of mind and happiness of heart (sukha) increases, until your mind flows with and absorbs into it as it enters the second pleasure jhana.
benefits: Regularly entering and experiencing the second pleasure jhana will strengthen your mind's ability to abide in the joyful presence of sukha throughout your day and create an open happy heart of joyful presence as a foundation for the spiritual happiness of the wholesome kusala qualities of gratitude, loving kindness, compassion, generosity, and gentleness in thought, speech and action.
14.purpose: Unify in the uplifting experience of joyfulness of mind and happiness of heart (sukha), with the blissful, pleasant feeling of piti significantly calmed and resting in your background peripheral awareness.
tips: The blissful, pleasant feeling of piti in the first pleasure jhana comes from growing seclusion of your mind from the six senses. The experience of sukha in the second pleasure jhana comes from further withdrawing of the mind from stimulation and a sense of unmoving stability due to increased intimacy with unification of the mind itself. Softening your mind's interest in the stimulation of the blissful, pleasant piti feeling will allow the experience of piti to rest in the background. Enjoying the less stimulated feeling of sukha will bring it to the foreground and make the joyfulness of your mind and the happiness in your heart (sukha) your main meditation object for the second pleasure jhana with a more refined pleasant feeling of piti in the background.

progression.criteria: You are comfortable developing and abiding in the second pleasure jhana for more extended periods, and your mind is inclining away from the excited quality of the joyfulness and the bubbliness of happiness of heart (sukha), toward a deeper, more still quality of happiness and contentment of heart.

15.name: Third Pleasure Jhana
15.subtitle: How to transform joyful happiness into equanimous contentment
15.duration: 60 minutes, 2-3 times daily, plus developing a continuity of contentment in your daily life is beneficial. The third pleasure jhana requires a simplification of your life, adherence to sila (morality) and inclining your mind toward that which is kusala (wholesome/skilful). Organised Buddhist meditation retreats create the perfect conditions for accelerating your practice from this point.

quote.text: "With the fading of joy & piti, equanimous, mindful, with clear comprehension, experiencing the pleasure of happiness within the body, they enter & dwell within the third jhana, of which the Noble Ones say: 'Equanimous & mindful, they have a pleasant abiding'."

15.overview: As the bubbly happiness of the Second Pleasure Jhana subsides, awareness rests in the subtler feeling of happy contentment, and your mind, losing interest in the uplifting feeling of joyfulness, flows with and absorbs into the feeling of happy contentment, entering the Third Pleasure Jhana.
benefits: Entering and abiding in the deep contentment and unmoving samadhi of the third pleasure jhana during seated meditation will create the conditions for maturing all Seven Awakening Factors once you finish seated meditation. This will allow you to develop deep insight after seated meditation and in your daily life.
15.purpose: Unify in the foreground in the subtle experience of happiness and contentment in your heart's centre, and allow the uplifting experience of joyfulness of mind to fade in the background peripheral awareness.

progression.criteria: The experience of happiness and pleasantness in the third pleasure jhana gradually becomes more refined and subtle, and the quality of contentment fills the foreground of your awareness, transforming into equanimity as the conditions for the fourth pleasure jhana develop.

16.name: Fourth Pleasure Jhana
16.subtitle: How to transform contentment into equanimous stillness
16.duration: 60 minutes, 2-3 times daily, plus developing continuity of equanimity in daily life. This stage requires a simplification of your life, adherence to sila (morality) and inclining your mind toward that which is kusala (wholesome/skilful). Organised Buddhist meditation retreats create the perfect conditions for accelerating your practice from this point.

quote.text: "Furthermore, with the abandoning of sukha & dukkha, as with the previous passing away of happiness & unhappiness, a meditator enters & dwells in the fourth jhana, which is neither pleasant nor unpleasant and contains mindfulness purified by equanimity."

16.overview: As happiness of the third pleasure jhana calms, your mind, resting in neutral contentment, free from happiness and pleasant or unpleasant feelings, will flow with and absorb into an extremely quiet, serene stillness, with clear mindfulness and unmoving equanimity, entering the fourth pleasure jhana.
benefits: Entering and abiding in the deep equanimity and unmoving samadhi of the fourth pleasure jhana will create the conditions for your mind to mature all Seven Awakening Factors when you finish seated meditation and develop deep vipassana insight in your daily life.
16.purpose: Unify in the foreground with the experience of neutral contentment, free from happiness, free from pleasant or unpleasant feelings, while allowing happiness and pleasure to fade into your background, peripheral awareness.

progression.criteria: You are ready to progress to training for Sotapanna: Stream Entry. Your skill in the samatha (calm) part of the Noble Eightfold Path is now mature, and mindfulness of breathing and accessing the jhanas becomes your daily meditation practice, integrated with periods of insight practice after emerging from jhana, and then carried into walking meditation and mindfulness in daily activities.

00.name: Diaphragmatic Breathing
00.subtitle: How to transform stress breathing into diaphragmatic breathing.
00.overview: Your first step is to learn to access relaxation and calm by retraining any stress-breathing patterns that may be present from your busy day. Simple changes in the way you breathe will lower stress and anxiety and prepare your breathing patterns for mindfulness of breathing in Skill 05.
benefits: This Skill will desensitise your mind's tendency to respond to stress and anxiety in daily life.
00.purpose: Retrain your breathing patterns to settle the experience of stress and anxiety in preparation for deeper states of calm and insight during mindfulness of breathing.
tips: For insight, be curious about how breathing in your chest is related to stress and how it makes you feel. Also, explore slow, diaphragmatic breaths and how they can transform the feeling of stress and anxiety into one of relaxation and calm.

progression.criteria: You experience a feeling of relaxation and ease after taking slow breaths in your belly, and diaphragmatic breathing in your belly happens naturally during your meditation and for a while after you have finished meditating.

01.name: Body Relaxation
01.subtitle: How to transform physical restlessness into body relaxation
01.duration: Initially 20 minutes, gradually increasing to 30 minutes

quote.text: "A meditator, having gone to the wilderness, to the shade of a tree, or a secluded place, sits down, folds their legs crosswise, holds their body erect and arouses mindfulness in the forefront of their mind."

01.overview: Your next step is to increase your body awareness by enjoying how nice it feels to relax your body with slow, gentle breathing. This step helps to alleviate feelings of physical restlessness related to stress and enhances body awareness in preparation for mindfulness of breathing in Skill 05.
benefits: This Meditation Skill will teach you how to lower your experience of physical restlessness and access the first stage of meditation, feeling comfortable in your body.
01.purpose: To teach your mind to find enjoyment in relaxing your body and to settle stress-based restlessness as preparation for mindfulness of your body.
tips: Tune into how nice it feels to be present with these simple experiences: this is the key to deepening meditation.

progression.criteria: You are ready to progress when you experience periods of feeling relaxed and comfortable during your meditation, and you understand how to settle physical restlessness with slow, softening belly breaths.

02.name: Mind Relaxation
02.subtitle: How to transform mental restlessness into mind relaxation

quote.text: "The meditator understands how the arising of un-arisen restlessness comes to be, and how to abandon restlessness once it has arisen; they also understand the conditions for the non-arising of restlessness once it has been abandoned."

02.overview: As you relax your body in Skill 01, a feeling of relaxation & comfort will grow, making you aware of the restlessness of your mind's interest in the past & future. In Skill 02, you will mentally relax this interest with slow breaths out through your nose while relaxing your eyelids to develop ease.
benefits: Teaches how to relax mental restlessness caused by intrusive thoughts with gentle breaths
02.purpose: Create space around thoughts and mind narratives by learning to relax your mind's interest in the past and future, thereby increasing awareness of your body.

progression.criteria: You are ready to progress to Meditation Skill 03: Mindful Presence when you can relax thoughts about the past and future when you notice them and feel physically and mentally comfortable, with no desire to get up from your meditation.

03.name: Mindful Presence
03.subtitle: How to transform sleepiness & dullness into mindful presence

quote.text: "Monks, whoever develops & pursues mindfulness immersed in the body encompasses whatever skilful qualities are on the side of clear knowing."

03.overview: As you enjoy relaxing during Skills 01 and 02, you will naturally develop an increased awareness of your body. As enjoyment grows, so will your mind's contentment with it, and a sense of being mindfully present within your body will also increase, removing sleepiness and dullness.
benefits: Teaches you how to stay present in your body throughout the day
03.purpose: Develop a natural mindfulness and clear comprehension of your body in preparation for mindfulness of breathing and insight during your daily activities.
tips: Once you have developed mindfulness of your body in Skill 03, you can use the presence of your body as a reference point for developing insight into the anatta (autonomous) nature of your mind's habits and teach your mind to let them go. Allocate the end of each meditation session to practice this formula on any distractions that arise, such as mind wandering and thinking, to refine your skill. The trick is to use the feeling of mindful presence in your body as a grounding (reference) point, resting your attention on the touch of your thumbs, and play a game by allowing your mind to wander. When you do, your attention will shift to a thought or memory, and gradually, you will get lost in it. When you notice this has happened, you can apply the GOSS Formula below to begin your insight game again. Enjoying the pleasant experience of contentment with the presence of your body will gradually weaken habitual mind wandering and forgetting.

progression.criteria: You feel contented sitting in meditation, mindful of your body, and have developed the skill of balancing energy while relaxing both your body and mind, thereby removing sleepiness and dullness. An increased sense of aware presence in your body will accompany this, reflected in a heightened sense of contentment. Congratulations, you have finished Cultivation 01.

04.name: Content Presence
04.subtitle: How to transform habitual forgetting into present contentment & happiness

quote.text: "When experiencing delusion within their mind, the meditator knows: 'there is delusion present within my mind'. When there is no delusion present within their mind, the meditator knows: 'There is no delusion present within my mind'."

04.overview: As a growing contentment with the presence of your body develops, you will naturally begin to enjoy it. You will then gently smile toward it with your eyes to align your mind with the enjoyment of your meditation, and to allow contentment with your meditation to grow, weakening habitual forgetting.
benefits: Teaches you how to find enjoyment in contentment and enjoy simple things in life
04.purpose: Train your mind to recognise the pleasant spiritual feeling available in letting go and to create the conditions for initial meditative joy by developing contentment to shorten the time your mind is lost in habitually forgetting your meditation.
tips: As your body and mind continue to relax and mental noise settles down, there will be times when you will feel breathing within your body. The appearance of the experience of breathing is a sign that relaxation is transitioning into calmness, and your sensitivity to these subtle bodily movements is increasing. It is essential not to bring your attention to your breathing and focus on it, as this may cause your mind to try to control it, leading to changes in your breathing patterns. Instead, continue to relax back into your body and enjoy your meditation. When your mind is ready to progress to Meditation Skill 05, you will find that your body begins to sense breathing by itself.

progression.criteria: You are ready to progress to Meditation Skill 05: Natural Breathing when you become naturally aware of the experience of your body breathing and find enjoyment in the relaxation and presence of your body. You will also notice that at this stage, the length of time you forget what you are doing during meditation and become lost in thinking will start to shorten. The appearance of the experience of your body breathing is the sign that your mind is ready for Skill 05. If the experience of your breathing is unclear at this stage, it is a sign that you need to spend more time learning to relax your body and mind. The quieter you become through relaxation, the more sensitive your body will become to your breathing. It is important to note that mind wandering and forgetting you are meditating for short periods is normal at this stage of meditation, will still be present at this time and will not fully settle down until the maturing of Skill 06. If you are feeling stuck and can't experience any pleasant feelings in your meditation in Skill 04, it is okay to move on to Skill 05. If your body feels present, and as you relax, you become aware of the movement of breathing in your body, it is okay to move on to Skill 05. Since all Skills are various stages of calm in meditation, you will still be practising Meditation Skill 04 each time you meditate and will gradually develop enjoyment in meditation anyway. Think of this approach as being stuck in the mud with a four-wheel drive. We could sit in the mud and dig away, or we could take a run-off and use that momentum to get to the other side. Removing the goal and finding enjoyment in meditation again will gradually bring back the pleasant feeling of meditation on its own.

05.name: Natural Breathing
05.subtitle: How to transform breath control into mindfulness of natural breathing

quote.text: "Always mindful, they breathe in; mindful, they breathe out."

05.overview: As your body and mind relax, you will become aware of the gentle stretch and relaxation of your body as it naturally breathes. Finding enjoyment in the gentle stretch and relaxation of each breath as your body breathes will increase your mindfulness and teach your mind how to let go of control.
benefits: This Meditation Skill will teach you how to be present with different experiences and situations within your life without the need to control them.
05.purpose: Train your mind to let go of breathing by finding the spiritual pleasantness of letting go, available in the natural flow of in- and out-breaths in your body to weaken any tendency of your mind to control your breathing.
tips: Develop insight by observing and softening any tendency of your mind to control your breathing. Breath control is characterised by tightness, tension, and breathing that does not settle or calm down as the meditation progresses. If you suspect breath control, allow a slow breath out through your nose, then relax and wait for the breath to draw back in by itself.

progression.criteria: You are ready to progress when, as a natural progression of relaxing & letting go, you move from being aware of each in and out-breath to being aware of the whole length of each in and out-breath without controlling it. It is important to note that it is only necessary to weaken habitual control at this stage, not to be completely free from it. If your mind, for example, causes your breathing to tighten so that it is difficult to breathe, then habitual control needs to be weakened before moving on. However, if while being aware of the breath, your mind calms down, a sign of this is being aware of the whole length of each breath, then it is perfectly ok to move on to the next stage in your meditation.

06.name: Whole Of Each Breath
06.subtitle: How to transform mind wandering into present breath awareness.

quote.text: "Breathing in long, they know: 'I am breathing in long'; or breathing out long, they know: 'I am breathing out long."

06.overview: As you enjoy the gentle stretch and relaxation of your body with each in and out-breath, your mind will develop intimacy with it. With this intimacy, the continuity of your mindful awareness will increase, allowing you to enjoy noticing the whole length of each in and out-breath.
benefits: Improve your focus on your present task in daily life
06.purpose: Increase mindfulness and clear comprehension of the whole of each in- and out-breath as it naturally flows in your body, to shorten forgetting and mind wandering.
tips: As your samadhi deepens, it is essential to remain mindful of not becoming too mentally calm and allowing your awareness to become dull and unclear. Smiling with your eyes and bringing that smile to the subtle, pleasant feeling of each breath, really enjoying it, will keep Hindrance 07: Gross Dullness away.

progression.criteria: You find enjoyment in being aware of the whole length of each breath in & out-breath, without effort and without habitually forgetting your meditation object (the breath) and feel confident in your ability to settle any mind wandering by applying the GOSS Formula when it occurs. Mind wandering does not completely stop at this stage of meditation and will continue in more subtle forms until Skill 09 when your attention sustains. As your mind and body relax and mindfulness develops, the time your mind wanders will shorten. It is how quickly you notice that your mind has wandered from your breath and body, and mindfulness returns that is most important here.

07.name: Breath Sensations
07.subtitle: How to transform gross dullness into clear breath sensation.
07.duration: 45 minutes. Due to the increased time it takes to develop calm increase your meditation time by 5 minutes.

quote.text: "When sloth & torpor are present within them, the meditator knows: 'There is sloth & torpor present within me'. When there is no sloth & torpor present within them, the meditator knows: 'There is no sloth & torpor present within me'."

07.overview: As your body, breathing, and mind calm, you can now begin to relax the habitual wandering of your attention. In MIDL we do this by shifting the focus of attention from the whole length of each breath, to resting on the experience of breathing at the tip of our nose.
benefits: This Meditation Skill will teach you how to increase your focus on the present task by developing calm within your mind rather than through effort.
07.purpose: Increase mindfulness and clear comprehension of the elemental qualities of breath sensations to increase calm and remove the conditions for gross dullness.
tips: To transition from Skill 07 to Skill 08, you will calm your mind's perception of breath length by calming your mind's perception of time.

progression.criteria: You are ready to progress when you feel confident in your ability to remove the conditions supporting Gross Dullness before it arises, and you clearly perceive the changing elemental qualities of your breathing at the tip of your nose without effort or strain and without forgetting them.

08.name: One Point of Sensation
08.subtitle: How to transform subtle dullness into tranquil clarity of sensation.

quote.text: "The meditator knows how the arising of un-arisen tranquillity as an awakening factor comes to be and how, once arisen, tranquillity as an awakening factor reaches maturity through cultivation."

08.overview: While smiling, allow the growing feeling of pleasantness, joy, and tranquillity to unfold. Your mind will become deeply calm, and attention will naturally rest on a single point of breath sensation, clearly aware of sensations at that point while maintaining peripheral awareness of your whole body.
benefits: Bring stability and calm to your mind
08.purpose: Calm the intellectual functions of your mind and remove subtle dullness by relaxing the perception of time and increasing the clarity of breath sensation.
tips: As you develop intimacy with the sensation within the length of each breath at the tip of your nose, the experience of calm and tranquillity of your mind will grow. Due to increasing calm and tranquillity, your mind's perception of time will begin to fade, and so will your perception of the length of each breath. This is experienced as attention becomes steady and firm on the one point of breath sensation.

progression.criteria: As a natural progression of letting go, you become aware of your attention resting on one point of breath sensation. Awareness of those sensations is clear to you, and there is a distinct experience of unmoving tranquillity in peripheral awareness. Due to the immaturity of meditative joy and tranquillity, there will still be some subtle wandering and restlessness within your attention. These two hindrances will calm in Meditation Skill 09: Sustained Attention by increasing enjoyment & tranquillity.

09.name: Sustained Attention
09.subtitle: How to transform subtle wandering into sustained attention.

quote.text: "When their mind is undistracted, the meditator knows: 'My mind is undistracted'. When their mind is distracted, they know: 'My mind is distracted'."

09.overview: Through continued momentum in the enjoyment of letting go and maturity of tranquillity, your attention will gradually become stable on one point of breath sensation, by itself, with your attention no longer wandering to thoughts or distractions.
benefits: This Meditation Skill will teach you to bring the first five Awakening Factors to mind so that your mind views your life through the wholesome qualities of mindfulness, curiosity, balanced effort, joy and tranquillity.
09.purpose: Sustain the focus of your attention on breath sensation, to tranquilise the intellectual functions of your mind and calm subtle mind wandering.
tips: Meditate only by Letting Go: At this stage of meditation, it is essential to learn how to transition between Markers 01-09 in mindfulness of breathing, not by 'doing' each Marker, but rather by allowing them to arise as a natural progression of relaxation and letting go, with clear comprehension. As you relax and let go, take an interest in how the development of Markers 01-09 establishes the first Five Awakening Factors: mindfulness, curiosity, balanced effort, meditative joy, & tranquillity.

progression.criteria: When your attention no longer wanders from your meditation object and effortlessly sustains (rests) on one point of breath sensation. There will still be sensory experiences and (might be) thoughts in the background, but they no longer draw your attention away from your meditation object. You will still have sensory experience within your peripheral awareness, including some fleeting thoughts, but your attention will no longer move out to them.
